Question
========

A standard `r strdie`-sided [die](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dice) was rolled `r n` times, and the results were organized into the [pie chart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pie_chart){target="blank"} shown below.

```{r echo=F,fig.width=6,fig.height=6}
size = 1.2
ps = counts/100
cp = cumsum(c(0,ps,1))
mids = (cp[2:(ns+1)]+cp[1:ns])/2
par(mar=c(0,0,0,0))
plot(0,0,type="n",xlim=c(-size,size),ylim=c(-size,size))
th = seq(0,2*pi,length.out=1000)
lines(cos(th),sin(th))
for(a in cp){
  lines(c(0,cos(a*2*pi)),c(0,sin(a*2*pi)))
}
lines(c(1,size),c(0,0),lwd=3)
for(a in seq(0.1,0.9,0.1)){
  lines(c(cos(a*2*pi),1.13*cos(a*2*pi)),c(sin(a*2*pi),1.13*sin(a*2*pi)))
  text(1.19*cos(a*2*pi),1.19*sin(a*2*pi),a*100)
}
for(a in seq(0.05,0.95,0.1)){
  lines(c(cos(a*2*pi),1.10*cos(a*2*pi)),c(sin(a*2*pi),1.10*sin(a*2*pi)))
  text(1.16*cos(a*2*pi),1.16*sin(a*2*pi),a*100)
}
for(a in seq(0.01,0.99,0.01)){
  lines(c(cos(a*2*pi),1.04*cos(a*2*pi)),c(sin(a*2*pi),1.04*sin(a*2*pi)))
}
for(i in 1:ns){
  a = mids[i]
  text(0.7*cos(a*2*pi),0.7*sin(a*2*pi),(1:n)[i])
}
text(1.15,0.04,0)
text(1.15,-0.04,100)
```

Answerlist
--------
* Evaluate $\#[\mathbf{x}<`r b1`]$.
* Evaluate $\#[\mathbf{x}>`r b2`]$.
* Evaluate $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c3`|<`r r3`]$.
* Evaluate $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c4`|>`r r4`]$.
* Evaluate half-integer boundary $b$ such that $\#[\mathbf{x}<b] = `r n5`$.
* Evaluate half-integer boundary $b$ such that $\#[\mathbf{x}>b] = `r n6`$.
* Evaluate `r wrd7` radius $r$ such that $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c7`|<r] = `r n7`$.
* Evaluate `r wrd8` radius $r$ such that $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c8`|>r] = `r n8`$.


Solution
========

The first 4 questions involve adding up frequencies of the indicated intervals. The last 4 questions can be done by guessing and checking until something works.

Answerlist
--------
* There are `r n1` measurements less than `r b1`. So, $\#[\mathbf{x}<`r b1`]=`r n1`$.
* There are `r n2` measurements more than `r b2`. So, $\#[\mathbf{x}>`r b2`]=`r n2`$.
* There are `r n3` measurements closer than `r r3` units from `r c3`. So, $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c3`|<`r r3`]=`r n3`$.
* There are `r n4` measurements further than `r r4` units from `r c4`. So, $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c4`|>`r r4`]=`r n4`$.
* A boundary at $b=`r b5`$ has `r n5` measurements less than it. So, $\#[\mathbf{x}<`r b5`]=`r n5`$.
* A boundary at $b=`r b6`$ has `r n6` measurements more than it. So, $\#[\mathbf{x}>`r b6`]=`r n6`$.
* An interval with radius $r=`r r7`$ around center `r c7` contains `r n7` measurements. So, $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c7`|<`r r7`]=`r n7`$.
* An interval with radius $r=`r r8`$ around center `r c8` excludes `r n8` measurements.  So, $\#[|\mathbf{x}-`r c8`|>`r r8`]=`r n8`$.
